Both newspapers, however, sinking party differences for the good of the country, in order to give the port of Hobart a fair deal, published facts and figures that must astound not only honorable members, but the people generally.
- They stopped discussion here when we were " gagged."

- I really hope that the honorable member for Franklin will follow me in this debate, and speak to the point as he did before; and that before he resumes his seat he will intimate to the Government of the day that, at an early date, he will insist on the Inter-State Commission exercising all the powers they possess to try to break down the existing state of things. From the remarks of the honorable member for Wimmera one would think that honorable members on this side of the House, and the Labour party generally, were totally opposed to immigration, or the introduction of people to settle on the land. Personally, I warmly welcome any one who comes here to settle, because every newcomer relieves the man who is already here of a certain part of the burden he is bearing. Every man that we can bring here from any country, who is white, and a worker, will benefit Australia, but we do not want men brought from London to compete with the men that we have in our cities at the present time. We want people to come here from other parts of the world to settle our lands, and to produce wealth, because we believe that that country is the wealthiest that nourishes the greatest number of happy and healthy individuals. When the honorable member for Wimmera was speaking the other day of the recent enormous increase of population in Victoria by means of immigration, I interjected that a State member had been reported to have said that every immigrant coming into Victoria had cost somewhere about £800. I do not know whether that is so or not, but I also intimated that Victoria was not retaining its population, and the honorable member replied that I should read up the statistics.
- What can you expect with the present Government?

- I have looked up the statistics, and, fearing that I might have read them wrongly, I this morning consulted the statistician to make sure that I had read them correctly. I find it stated on page 9 of Bulletin No. 19 for July, 1913, that nominated and selected immigrants had arrived in Victoria during the first seven months of 1913 to the number of 6,463. Nevertheless, on page 4, the statistician shows that, for the first six months of 1913, the excess of emigration over immigration for Victoria was 275.
- The record of the Watt Ministry has been to deplete the population, and increase the number of members of Parliament.
- Order ! I must ask the honorable member for Adelaide not to interject.
- An ordinary interjection is in order in ordinary circumstances. I do not want to be bitten by the Chairman every time I open my mouth.
- Order ! It is not the first time the honorable member has spoken during the course of the speech of the honorable member for Denison. The honorable member has been continually interrupting.
- Not continually.
- Very frequently.
- I do not want to be jumped on by the Chairman every time I make an interjection.
- I have already pointed out on other occasions that there is less justification for an honorable member interrupting who is on the same side as the speaker.
- It was not an interruption; it was an interjection.
- The honorable member for Adelaide does not make an interjection only. He frequently utters lengthy sentences - a practice which I cannot allow.
- You will get yourself into trouble, Mr. Chairman, if you lecture honorable members in that way.
- I am here to see that debate is carried on according to the Standing Orders. If I cannot maintain order, I shall see that something else is done.
- I shall interject when I wish to.
- I hope the honorable member will not assume that defiant attitude.
- I am not defiant. 1 am quite respectful.
- The honorable member is quite out of order in making interjections when an honorable member is speaking.
- So is any other honorable member out of order in that case.
- Undoubtedly; and it is my duty to check interjections if they are made to any undue degree, as has been the case with the honorable member for Adelaide.
- I differ from you.

- The interjections of the honorable member for Adelaide have been rather . helpful to me, as he has reminded me of the fact that the Victorian Government are increasing the number of members in the State Parliament, whereas, according to the figures I have quoted, the population of Victoria is on the decrease. It is remarkable to find that the States that hold their population, and are settling people on the land, are New South Wales and Western Australia - the States which have Labour Governments. They are bringing out immigrants, quite a number of whom have come from the Old Land since Labour Governments have been in power there. In each of these States we find that the immigrants are retained, and surely this ought to refute the allegation made in this House, and outside, that the Labour party, and Labour members generally, are opposed to the peopling of the lands of the country. We are not at all opposed - at least, I am not - to immigration, but we welcome all, provided they are able to go on to the land, and do not become competitors in an over-crowded labour market.
- It is disgraceful-
- Order! How dare the honorable member interject?
- I hope the honorable member for Adelaide will not continue this attitude of insolence towards the Chair, otherwise he will be dealt with.
- I did not mention the Chair; I did not look at you.
- I am too old a parliamentary hand not to know when insolence is meant, and I wish to inform the honorable member that I cannot tolerate it.

- As a point of order, may I say that I have certain privileges in this Chamber, and that I certainly object to your calling me insolent merely because I interject. At the same time, it is not uncommon for an honorable member to call " order " when another honorable member interjects.
- It is quite out of order for an honorable member who is not in the chair to call "order."

- Protectionists in particular should feel indebted to the honorable member for Maribyrnong for bringing under our notice the existing state of affairs in regard to the sugar industry in Queensland. No State suffers more than Tasmania owing to what I may call the subsidizing of the growing of sugar in Queensland.
- What about jam?
- Holloa! Is there a split in the party?
- Order!

- We know that, no matter on 'which side of the House Queensland members may sit, they always work hand in hand in regard to anything affecting the interests of their State; and Tasmanian members may learn a lesson thereby. The honorable member for Capricornia has nothing to be alarmed at if white labour in the sugar industry be insisted on. I may say, however, that when this question comes before the House I shall assist the honorable member for Maribyrnong to have the duty removed if black labour is employed. It is most unfair that growers who use black labour should reap the benefit.
- Hear hear! And I shall help the honorable member to do it.

- We all know how hard the honorable member for Herbert works in. the interest of the sugar-growing community. We know that that honorable member is in favour of a White Australia, but, at the same time, we cannot expect him to speak otherwise than he has on behalf of the industry, and when he interjected during the speech of the honorable member for Maribyrnong, I take it that uppermost in his mind were the interests of his district. I hope the honorable member will not think I am dealing too severely with him if I say now that I certainly shall not assist him to retain the duty if sugar is to be produced by coloured labour. Notwithstanding the honorable member's pleading and winning way, I shall refuse to take any such step, but, on the other hand, will help the honorable member for Maribyrnong, who has placed southern consumers under a debt of gratitude.
- The honorable member will not improve matters if we get our sugar from Java or the West Indies.
- What does it matter where the sugar is grown if it is by means of coloured labour?
- I have always understood that the duty was put on in order that we might have white-grown sugar.
- The honorable member for Capricornia knows that, too.

- We do not desire to do any injury to the sugar industry in Queensland. I have been wondering whether the information contained in a monthly share-list that is received by honorable members has anything to do with the present position. In that share-list we read -

quote.para: As mentioned above, business in Industrials has been more general. Colonial sugar, however, retains pride of place, there being a constant demand, and the shares, allowing for the dividend, are £1 higher, at£42 17s. 6d. The yield to the investor is 5$ per cent., and issues of bonus shares can confidently be expected. We pointed out above the advantage of bonus issues over those at par, and those who buy sugars now should have no reason to be dissatisfied with the growth of the investment. As we said last month, the stock is regaining its old-time popularity, and we look for a continuous rise for some time to come.

talk.start.para: - The removal of the bounty gives them nearly £100,000 a year.
- Why not call other honorable members to order when they interject?

- I wish to explain to the honorable member for Adelaide that I am quite willing to turn a deaf ear to any casual interjection, but the honorable member frequently goes beyond that, and utters quite lengthy and elaborate sentences.
- Quite a lengthy and elaborate sentence was uttered by the honorable member for Franklin.
- I must be allowed to exercise a little judgment in these matters.
- Then exercise it impartially, Mr. Chairman.

- I wish to assure the honorable member that so long as he does not appear to be interfering with the speech of an honorable member who has possession of the floor, and shouting long sentences in the ear of the Hansard reporter directly in front of him, I shall not interfere.
- If you like, Mr. Chairman, I shall take a seat on the other side.
- If the honorable member is entitled , to a seat opposite, I have no objection at all; and I hope that, on this understanding, we shall get along a little more pleasantly.
- I had not the slightest intention-
-Order ! I call on the honorable member for Denison.

- You, Mr. Chairman, say that you are going to use certain discretion. It is either right or wrong for an honorable member to interject, and if it is wrong, he ought not to do so. I contend that there is no discretion on your part to allow any honorable member to interject.
- The honorable member for Kennedy knows perfectly well that there is always a discretion exercised by the Chair.
- No, I do not; and I hope you will not attribute such a ruling to me.
- The honorable member for Kennedy himself exercised such a discretion for a considerable time, and it is his example that I am endeavouring, to the best of my ability, to follow.
- I wish to tell you,

speech.para: Mr. Chairman, that I never ruled that I had discretion in that way, and if you think there is discretion, you are absolutely wrong.

talk.start.para: - I do not know whether, under the circumstances, I am expected to keep my remarks connected.
- Go on; the honorable member was speaking about Colonial sugar shares as a good investment.

- And, no doubt, they are a good investment. I was of opinion, until this morning, that if the duty were removed, sugar would come down in price; but a gentleman has informed me that the great combine that controls the industry has power outside the country, and that it is very doubtful whether such effect would follow if the duty were removed to-morrow. We are told by the Attorney-General that the Government are looking into the matter of the trusts, and are going to deal with them - that all that we have to do is to bring forward evidence, and proceedings will immediately be taken. This, however, we have been told ever since the Government came into power, and yet the trusts are going on in their own sweet way. The other day the honorable member for Oxley brought under the notice of the Government a glaring case of a trust, but not the slightest attention was paid to him; indeed, from what was said here, and subsequently outside, one would think that there had been really misrepresentations made in this respect. The Age of 5th November last distinctly says that there is a' trust existing at the present time in Australia, and that it is connected with a larger trust that has a capital of £40,000,000. The Age, in its article, says -

quote.para: The American Beef Trust is extending its grip upon the Commonwealth of Australia. What was eighteen months ago a matter of ill-defined rumours of the intentions of one of the most important members of this vast international combination of American capitalists and refrigerating, packing, and meat selling experts, is now a matter of well authenticated fact. The trust is here, and by1st September, 1914, at latest, the largest establishment for the freezing or chilling of Australian meat for export, which it has acquired, will be in full working order. Minor establishments, either already acquired from their former Australian owners, or in process of acquisition, will be under full trust control probably before that date.

speech.para: We have the Attorney-General, the Prime Minister, and others asking that proof shall be brought forward ; but they might as well say straight out that they have no power to deal with trusts. The Age article proceeds -

quote.para: It is said 1,000 men are at work on then week by week. They will constitute an establishment capable of killing and freezing 450 cattle and 2,000 sheep per day, or, allowing 300 working days in the year, 135,000 head of cattle and 600,000 sheep per annum. As a new " competitor " for the cattle of the northern State, and the northern rivers of New South Wales, the advent of the trust works is regarded with feelings of great satisfaction by cattle raisers.

speech.para: Something ought to be done in regard to this important question of trusts. There is no doubt that trusts are getting a hold in Australia, and if steps are not taken immediately we shall have as much trouble to get rid of them as is experienced in the United States. There is another matter I should like to refer to, and that is the statement which has been continually made outside the House by Ministers as to the alleged extravagance of the Fisher Government - the waste of money in the enormous expenditure alleged to have been made by the late Administration ; but honorable members surely must have realized ere this that the people outside are beginning to think for themselves, and that Ministers' statements in this direction will not carry any weight. I congratulate the Treasurer upon his Budget-papers. They "were excellently compiled, and in such a concise form that their meaning could be quickly grasped. They have been a valuable aid to myself, and, I believe, to the people of Australia. From them we find that the actual Commonwealth expenditure for 1912-13, during the Fisher regime, was £23,111,462, while the estimated expenditure for 1913-14 during the present regime, is £27,246,747 - or an increase of' £4,135,285. The Ministers' excuse for this increase is that it is owing to commitments by the late Government. Are present Ministers responsible for what the late Government suggested might be done? They are not carrying out in their administration many of the acts of the late Government. For instance, the late Government would never have thought of knocking off 7d. per day from the office cleaners, in order to make a saving to the Commonwealth. That they have done so is a disgrace.

talk.start.para: - Who did it?
- It is said that the Public Service Commissioner did it.
- It is the first I have heard of it.

- There is no honorable member who would not assist the Treasurer to have justice done to these people. I believe they have to come to work at 5 o'clock in the morning in order to complete their work before the other members of the Commonwealth Service attend at their offices. Go to the waterside, or to any other sphere of work, and such attendance would be called overtime, and double time, or time and a half would be paid; yet we find the present Government cutting a paltry 7d. per day off these office cleaners, and that in a wealthy country like this, where the wealth is increasing by leaps and bounds, as so ably shown by the honorable member for Hindmarsh. I suppose this is where the saving of a million is made that the Prime Minister boasts of. To my amazement, the other day, when an honorable member was speaking, the Prime Minister interjected, " How can you get a knowledge of all the Departments in five months ?" How do Ministers get the knowledge enabling them to' save this million ? The Treasurer, in his reply to this debate, should show the country where this million has been saved. In my opinion, it is all a myth - a placard put out for the purpose of trying to deceive those it is thought will be again asked to exercise the franchise at a general election. However, we shall be able to tell the people of Australia that this saving has not been made, and that the Government of the day are afraid to interfere with a piece of the legislation placed on the statute-book by the Fisher Government. The gentleman who opposed me in Denison had the courage to say straight out that he was against the land tax, and would repeal it if he were returned. Have the Government done anything along this line, or along the lines they suggested before they got into power ? Decidedly not. So I hope we shall soon hear the last of this cry by responsible Ministers that the Labour party were responsible for an enormous expenditure. We are reverting to the old system of government - the good old borrowing policy. We find the Government of Australia launching out on a borrowing policy to construct works that are not of a productive nature. They are borrowing for military purposes - a thing unknown even in the Old Land. I wish to say with emphasis that I am strongly opposed to borrowing, even from our Trust Funds, the sum of £175,000 for the purpose of installing machinery at Cockatoo Island, in New South Wales, to make munitions of war and for the construction of ships. Such machinery should be paid for out of revenue. In addition, "the Government purpose to borrow for conduits. We all know that conduits are of a very perishable nature. It is said that they will last fifteen years, but that is a matter of opinion, and it is questionable whether long before that time something will not have superseded them, in which case they will have very little value. We should do all this work out of revenue. The Fisher Government did it out of revenue, and the present Government should continue along the same lines.

debateinfo.title: DEATH OF THE HONORABLE E. A. ROBERTS

debate.para: Motion (by Mr. Joseph Cook) agreed to-

quote.para: That the Chairman do now leave, the chair, report progress, and ask leave to sit again.

talker.role: Prime Minister and Minister of Home Affairs
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: . - In submitting the motion with which I intend to conclude my remarks, one scarcely knows what to say in such bewildering circumstances. One fatality following upon the heels of another makes one wonder who will be the next to add to this ghastly toll which is towering up so far as this Federal Parliament is concerned. It makes one wonder if there is not some special fatality attaching to our meeting here, and what may be the cause of it. But whatever may be the cause, it is certainly our melancholy duty to make mention of the fact that another brilliant life has closed. I am quite sure I echo the sentiments of every honorable member in this House when I say that the personality which has just ebbed away in the Hall was a very brilliant one indeed, full of promise . for the future, and one of whom the highest hopes were entertained by all members of this Chamber. It seemed to be only a matter of time 'when he would be fulfilling the highest functions attached to the government of the country, and in connexion with our Parliamentary Government. I cannot voice too highly my appreciation of his splendid intellectual abilities, and of his high devotion to duty. I am not quite sure whether his devotion to his duties here has not tended to hasten the termination of his life. He was here at the beginning of each sitting, he was here at its close, and he was generally here throughout the interval between those two points. I verily believe that his sheer devotion to his duties has helped to undermine his health, which it now appears was not robust, until it brought about the result that we have witnessed to-day.

speech.para: I do not know that I can add very much more. One's feelings get the better of one's brain at such a time, when these fatalities follow each other in such quick succession. I can only add the expression of my great sorrow at the closing of the life which we now mourn. I hope that those who are near and dear to our departed friend will be comforted in their sad hour of trial, and that that help which we are unable to furnish will be given to them to sustain them in this their time of need. We do not understand all that is taking place in connexion with these matters. It is our duty, therefore, to content ourselves here and now with recording the fact that another life, full of promise, big with hope, and with legitimate aspirations, all in the bloom and ardour of a full manhood, has been cut short. The sun has gone down while it is yet day. I only hope that those of us who remain may do our duty in our day and generation, and that we shall hasten to do. it, because we do not know how soon we, too, may be summoned to our account. I hope that when the tally of our life comes to be taken, we shall be found to have done our duty - as I firmly and conscientiously believe he whose loss we now mourn did his. I move -

quote.para: That this House places on record its high appreciation of the great public services of the late member for Adelaide, the late Honorable E. A. Roberts, and tenders its sincere sympathy to the bereaved family of an eminent citizen, whose untimely decease is a great loss to the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: .- A few minutes ago a great personality, a member of this House, and a colleague of my own, passed away to that bourne whence no traveller returns. The Prime Minister has spoken kindly of his talents, and I agree with every word which the honorable gentleman' said in that regard. His work was, of course, more keenly appreciated by my colleagues and myself than it could be by those who were not so intimately associated with him in political matters. I join, first of all, with the Prime Minister in conveying to the widow and children whom the late Mr. Roberts has left behind him our sympathy and our appreciation of the great services he has rendered his State and the Commonwealth in his public capacity and otherwise. He was, as you know, Mr. Speaker, a man of singular intellectual ability, of a disposition strenuous and arduous. It is probable, as has been remarked before, that his desire to carry out his public duties faithfully contributed to and hastened his end. The Prime Minister seemed to indicate in his utterances that there is a fatality attaching to our meeting in this place.
- No, I did not intend to suggest that.

- I think there is. I have stated on previous occasions that, in my opinion, this chamber and this building are not healthy places. These are occasions upon which we do not desire to enter upon any controversial matters, but it is our bounden duty to look after those who live, seeing that .we cannot help the dead back to life. I trust that, as my late colleague is no longer with us, the widow and children will be comforted by those Powers who are unseen, but by whom many are comforted and consoled in the hour of trial and suffering. Apart from that consolation, I feel sure that the widow, children, relatives, and friends of the late Mr. E. A. Roberts will be consoled by the feeling that his public services have done something to add to the comfort of others, since, according to his lights, he lost no opportunity in his public capacity to help his fellow man. I join with the Prime Minister in the statement that, while it is yet our privilege to render some public service, we should not delay in giving the best that we have. I can only add, at a time like this, that if these visitations are likely to be as frequent as they have been, few of the original members of the Federal Parliament will be here in the course of a very few years. The mortality amongst them has undoubtedly been very great, and I hope that we have seen the last of these tragic endings to the lives of representatives of the people in this Parliament. I may be allowed, on behalf of those on this side of the chamber, who were nearly associated with the late Mr. Roberts, to express my appreciation of the kind remarks of the Prime Minister, and the many similar remarks expressed privately by honorable members on the other side. 1 concur in the motion submitted by the Prime Minister expressing our appreciation of the services which the late honorable member for Adelaide rendered his country, and I again express the hope that those near and dear to him will be comforted in this the day of their trial and loss.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative, honorable members standing in their places.
Motion (by Mr. Joseph COOK) agreed to-

quote.para: That Mr. Speaker be requested to transmit the foregoing resolution and a copy of the addresses delivered thereon to Mrs. Roberts.

debate.para: Motion (by Mr. Joseph Cook) agreed to-

quote.para: That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Thursday next, at 10.30 a.m.
House adjourned at 6.5 p.m.
